pages.text: Chancelloria comes from the Cambrian, with fossils found across the globe. It is a large chancelloriid, growing up to 20 cm in height. Despite appearances, Chancelloria is not a sponge, although was considered as one up until 2008, with recent phylogenetic studies placing them within Eumetazoa, between Placoza and Cnidaria. It was cylindrical in shape and was adorned with star-shaped spines, which got tighter and larger near its top, surrounding and opening.

The generic name derives from the Latinised place-name 'Chancellor Peak', near to where the first fossils were found, with the peaks name further deriving its name from Chancellor Sir John Boyd of Ontario, in honour of settling a dispute in 1886 between the Canadian Pacific Railway and the Canadian Government.
